model_input:
[Task Description]
You will be given DIALOGUE CONTEXT and MEMORY.
You task is to evaluate MEMORY based on the criterion.
Please make sure you read and understand these instructions carefully. Please keep this document open while reviewing, and refer to it as needed.

[Criterion]
Helpfulness (1-5): How much the MEMORY provides helpful information for a language model, representing Speaker A, to generate a proper next response based on DIALOGUE CONTEXT. An helpful memory should contain sentences that are naturally structured, representing the development (e.g., causality, connection, etc) of two speakers' past interactions. These sentences should be phrased in a way such that the language model can easily identify important contextual cues related to DIALOGUE CONTEXT.

For your information:
A score of 1 means that most sentences in MEMORY do not benefit generating a next response OR are structured in a way that does not really tell us much about two speakers' past interactions (e.g., connection, relevancy, or development of events).
A score of 5 means that MEMORY contains some sentences providing information relevant to DIALOGUE CONTEXT. And, sentences in it should be naturally connected so the development/causality/relevancy of sentences is clearly demonstrated. Even the sentences that are not related to DIALOGUE CONTEXT are naturally phrased such that the language model can easily identify them as not beneficial.

[Evaluation Steps]
1. Read DIALOGUE CONTEXT and MEMORY carefully.
2. Rate MEMORY on a scale of 1-5 according to the criterion above.
3. Provide a brief explanation for your rating.

[Your Task]
DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
Speaker A: I was able to get the aluminum sheeting for my garbage. I'm going to install it today and I'll let you know how my raccoon problem goes.  Speaker B: I hope it goes well for you. How come you don't just leave small bowls of food out and befriend the raccoons? It would solve your problem a lot faster, especially because raccoon's are so smart. Bandicoot knows how to open and unlock so many things, it's makes it difficult to keep him out of trouble. Which is why I take him to work with me. Speaker A: Ohhh.  That would be bad. I really do not want more raccoons or other animals coming around.  I like them OK, but I do not want to have some diseased ones get close to the house.  Speaker B: Understandable. Have you ever tried contacting animal control? That's how I got Bandicoot. I was working that day and animal control came by explaining about needing fosters for raccoons. I thought it was weird, so I did it and began to work at the small raccoon cafe that is part of the zoo. I love it.  Speaker A: That is a good idea.  Maybe they could help move them to a safer area.  I have a lot of traffic around and they could get hit if they are coming to my place all the time.  Have you been able to teach your raccoon any tricks? Speaker B: The only trick I was able to teach him, that I deeply regret, was how locks worked. I thought it was cool at first, you know, to see a raccoon unlock a door. And now, I regret it so much. I've had to change the layout of my apartment and put deadbolts on my doors so that Bandicoot can't get out. And, he is sneaky about it. One time, he unlocked the pantry and was eating some cookies! It's like having a toddler that never grows up. Speaker A: That is bad I guess.  Do you keep all of your chemicals, poisons, and medications up and locked?  I would hate to think what might happen if Bandicoot got into any of that.  Hey, when you drive do you lock him up in a cage or let him wander around in the car?  That could be dangerous for you driving and he freaks out. Speaker B: All the chemicals and poisons are in a gated lock in the basement. The lock requires a specific key, which I have hidden in my drawers. For medication, I have a small box that I also keep locked up, but it's a combination lock, so Bandicoot isn't able to get into it. For driving, I bought a harness that keeps him strapped in the back seat, he can move a bit, but mostly sturdy. I put blankets down and his favorite toys so that he stays calm. Sometimes, I'll pass small snacks to keep him occupied. I also take the side streets to work so that it's not too much for him. What about you? When you foster dogs, do you put them in a cage when you drive? Speaker A: I do keep the dogs secured. You never knwo how they are going to react.  Most of them I only have for a few days, so I really do not get a chance to see how they will act in all situations.   Speaker B: Oh, does that make you want to adopt a dog? I know you said it makes you sad to see them come and go, so why not adopt one?

MEMORY:
1. Speaker B works at a Raccoon Cafe and takes care of Bandicoot, a raccoon.
2. Speaker B has been taking care of the raccoon for over a month and is interested in training it.
3. Speaker B believes raccoons can make good pets if cared for properly.
4. Speaker B has a dog named Bandicoot and is willing to bring him over for extra company.
5. Speaker A has not interacted closely with raccoons but admires them.
6. Speaker B considers raccoons intelligent and funny.

[OUTPUT]
Helpfulness Score:

raw_prediction: I have thought about it, but I'm not quite ready for the long-term commitment. Maybe in the future, once I have more stability in my schedule.
prediction:
Helpfulness Score: 3

Explanation: The MEMORY provides some useful contextual cues for generating a response in the DIALOGUE CONTEXT. It reveals that Speaker B works at a Raccoon Cafe and cares for a raccoon named Bandicoot, which correlates with the discussion about Bandicoot's behaviors and tricks. The details about Speaker B's interest in raccoons and their intelligence align with Speaker B's perspective shared in the dialogue. However, there are inaccuracies in the MEMORY, such as stating that Bandicoot is a dog when it is, in fact, a raccoon. Also, the information about Speaker A's attitude toward raccoons and an error about Speaker B's pet does not directly support the continuance of the current dialogue, as they do not provide any new or relevant insight that Speaker A could use to formulate a response. Therefore, MEMORY could be improved for higher relevance and accuracy, leading to a middle score.
